Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Travel
Indeed, He, the Exalted, says: "They know an outward [zahir] aspect of the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya], and of the Hereafter [al-akhira] they are heedless [ghafilun]." For rational sciences [al-'ulum al-'aqliyya] are divided into worldly [dunyawiyya] and otherworldly [ukhrawiyya]. The worldly are like the science of medicine, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and all crafts and industries. The otherworldly are like the science of the states of the heart [ahwal al-qalb] and the defects of deeds, and the knowledge [al-'ilm] of God, the Exalted, and His attributes and His actions, as We detailed in the Book of Knowledge. And these are two conflicting sciences ['ilman mutanafiyan]; I mean that whoever directs his concern to one of them until he delves deeply into it, his insight [basira] into the other is, for the most part, diminished. Therefore, 'Ali, may God be pleased with him, gave three parables for the world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhira]. He said: They are like the two pans of a scale, and like the east and the west, and like two co-wives: if you please one, you anger the other. For this reason, you see the clever ones [al-akyaas] in the affairs of the world [al-dunya] and in the science of medicine, arithmetic, geometry, and philosophy to be ignorant [juhhala] in the affairs of the Hereafter [al-akhira]. And the clever ones [al-akyaas] in the subtleties of the sciences of the Hereafter [al-akhira] are ignorant [juhhala] in most of the worldly sciences [al-'ulum al-dunya], because the power of the intellect [al-'aql] does not suffice for both matters together in most cases, so one of them becomes a barrier [man'] from perfection in the second. Therefore, He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, most of the people of Paradise are the simple-minded [al-bulh]," meaning simple-minded in the affairs of the world [al-dunya]. And Al-Hasan said in one of his sermons: "We have encountered people whom, if you saw them, you would say they are madmen, and if they encountered you, they would say you are devils." Whenever you hear something strange from the affairs of the religion [al-din], which the people of cleverness [ahl al-kiyasa] in the other sciences reject, do not let their rejection deceive you into not accepting it. For it is impossible for the traveler on the path to the east to find what exists in the west. Thus runs the affair of the world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhira]. Therefore, He, the Exalted, says: "They know an outward [zahir] aspect of the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya], and of the Hereafter [al-akhira] they are heedless [ghafilun]."

Have they not traveled through the earth and observed how was the end of those before them? They were greater than them in power, and they plowed the earth and built it up more than they have built it up, and their messengers came to them with clear evidences. And Allah would not ever have wronged them, but they were wronging themselves.
Then the end of those who did evil was the worst [consequence] because they denied the signs of Allah and used to ridicule them.
Allah begins creation; then He will repeat it; then to Him you will be returned.
And the Day the Hour appears the criminals will be in despair.
And there will not be for them among their [alleged] partners any intercessors, and they will [then] be disbelievers in their partners.
And the Day the Hour appears - that Day they will become separated.
And as for those who had believed and done righteous deeds, they will be in a garden [of Paradise], delighted.

Indeed, the heart [qalb] in seeking the matters of the world [dunya] becomes clear and unburdened, for the outward and inward assist each other in that. As for turning back to acts of worship [â€˜ibadat], it is forced, and the sincerity [ikhlas] of the heart and its presence [hudur] within it are not secured except at some times. So whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse his times in obedience [taâ€™a]. And whoever wishes for the scale of his good deeds [hasanat] to outweigh and the balances of his goodness [khayrat] to grow heavy, let him occupy most of his time with obedience. For if he mixes a righteous deed with an evil one, his affair is perilous, yet hope [rajaâ€™] is not cut off, and pardon [â€˜afw] from the generosity of Allah is awaited. Perhaps Allah, the Exalted, will forgive him by His bounty and generosity. This is what has been unveiled to the observers by the light of insight [nur al-basira]. If you are not of its people, then look to the address of Allah, the Exalted, to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith [iman]. And Allah, the Exalted, has made clear that the path to Him is the vigilant observance of times and populating them with litanies [awrad] on the path of constancy. The purpose of the sun and moon running in a precise, ordered calculation, and of the creation of shadow and light and the stars, is not to seek aid through them for worldly matters, but rather that you may know by them the measures of times, so you may occupy yourselves within them with acts of obedience and trade for the Abode of the Hereafter [dar al-akhira]. His statement, the Exalted, indicates that: **â€œAnd He is the One who made the night and the day in succession for whoever desires to remember or desires gratitude.â€** Meaning, one succeeds the other so that what was missed in one may be made up in the other, and He clarified that this is for remembrance [dhikr] and gratitude [shukr], nothing else. And the litanies [awrad] of the day are seven. The first litany is what is between the dawn [fajr] and sunrise, and it is a noble time. The swearing of Allah, the Exalted, by it indicates its nobility and virtue, as in His statement, the Exalted: **â€œSo exalted is Allah when you reach the evening and when you reach the morning.â€** For the time is equal, so how can they be equivalent when nature inclines towards one of them? ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
The Fourth Litany [al-wird] is what is between the zenith [al-zawal] and the completion of the Dhuhr prayer and its regular Sunnah. This is the shortest of the day's litanies and the most excellent of them. So, if he had performed ablution [wudu] before the zenith and was present in the mosque, then whenever the sun has passed its zenith and the caller to prayer [mu'adhdhin] begins the call [adhan], let him wait until the completion of the response to his call. Then let him rise to enliven what is between the call [adhan] and the establishment [iqamah], for it is the time of the appearance [al-izhar] which Allah, the Exalted, intended by His saying: "And when you appear [tazharun]" (30:18). And let him pray in this time four rak'ahs, not separating between them with a single salutation [taslimah wahidah]. Concerning this prayer alone, among all the other prayers of the day, some scholars have transmitted that he prays it with a single salutation, but that narration has been criticized. The school [madhhab] of Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him, is that he prays it two by two [mathna mathna] like all other supererogatory prayers [nawafil] and separates with a salutation, and it is that which the reports have confirmed as sound. And let him lengthen these rak'ahs, for in them the gates of the heaven are opened, as we have mentioned the report concerning it in the chapter on supererogatory prayer [salah al-tatawwu']. And let him recite in them Surah Al-Baqarah, or a surah from the Hundreds [al-mi'in], or four from the Repeated Verses [al-mathani]. For these are hours in which supplication [du'a'] is answered, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, loved that a deed be raised up for him within them. Then he prays Dhuhr in congregation after four long rak'ahs, as preceded, or short onesâ€”it is not fitting that he neglects them. Then let him pray after Dhuhr two rak'ahs, then four. For Ibn Mas'ud disliked that an obligatory prayer [fard] be followed by its like without a separation. And it is recommended [mustahabb] that he recite in this supererogatory prayer [nafilah] the Verse of the Throne [Ayat al-Kursi] and the end of Surah Al-Baqarah and the verses which we mentioned in the First Litany, so that this may combine for him between supplication [du'a'], remembrance [dhikr], recitation [qira'ah], prayer [salah], praise [tahmid], and glorification [tasbih] along with the nobility of the time.

Vol 4: Meditation
Indeed, the Qur'an has come urging reflection upon these signs [ayat], as Allah the Exalted has said: "Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs [ayat] for those of understanding [ulu al-albab]." And as He the Exalted has said: "And among His signs [ayat]..." from the beginning of the Qur'an to its end. So let us mention the manner of reflection upon some of the signs [ayat]. So from His signs [ayat] is the human [insan], created from a sperm-drop [nutfah]. And the closest thing to you is your own self [nafs], and within you are wonders [aja'ib] indicating the majesty of Allah the Exalted, which lifetimes would not suffice to stand upon a tenth of a tenth of them, while you are heedless [ghafil] of them. So O you who is heedless [ghafil] of your own self [nafs] and ignorant of it, how do you aspire to the knowledge [ma'rifah] of other than you? And Allah the Exalted has commanded you to contemplate [tadabbur] within your own selves [anfusikum] in His Mighty Book, saying: "And in yourselves [anfusikum]â€”will you not then see?" And He mentioned that you are created from a foul sperm-drop [nutfah qadhirah], saying: "Destroyed is man [insan]; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfah] He created him and destined him. Then He made the path easy for him. Then He causes him to die and be buried. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." And He the Exalted said: "And among His signs [ayat] is that He created you from dust, then, behold, you are human beings spreading [on earth]." And He the Exalted said: "Was he not a sperm-drop [nutfah] from semen emitted? Then he was a clinging clot ['alaqah]; then He created and proportioned." And He the Exalted said: "Did We not create you from a despised fluid [ma' mahin]? Then We placed it in a firm lodging [qararin makin], for a known term [qadar ma'lum]." And He said: "Does man [insan] not see that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfah]? Then at once he is a clear adversary." And He said: "Indeed, We created man [insan] from a sperm-drop [nutfah] mixed [amshaj]..." Then He mentioned how He made the sperm-drop [nutfah] a clinging clot ['alaqah], and the clinging clot ['alaqah] a chewed lump [mudghah], and the chewed lump [mudghah] bones. He the Exalted said: "And certainly did We create man [insan] from an extract of clay. Then We placed him as a sperm-drop [nutfah] in a firm lodging [qararin makin]. Then We made the sperm-drop [nutfah] into a clinging clot ['alaqah]..." So the repeated mention of the sperm-drop [nutfah] in the Mighty Book is not for one to merely hear its word and abandon reflection upon its meaning. So look now at the sperm-drop [nutfah]â€”it is a droplet of foul water; if left for an hour for the air to strike it, it would spoil and become putrid. How did the Lord of lords bring it forth from the loins and the ribs? And how did He bring together the male and the female and cast affection [ulfah] and love [mahabbah] into their hearts [qulub]? And how did He lead them by the chain of love [mahabbah] and desire [shahwah] to union? And how did He extract the sperm-drop [nutfah] from the man by the movement of intercourse? And how did He draw the menstrual blood from the depths of the veins and gather it in the womb? Then how did He create the newborn from the sperm-drop [nutfah] and nourish it with the water of menstruation until it grew, increased, and became large? And how did He make the sperm-drop [nutfah], which is white and radiant, into a red clinging clot ['alaqah]? Then how did He make it a chewed lump [mudghah]? Then how did He divide the parts of the sperm-drop [nutfah], which are equal and similar, into bones, nerves, veins, tendons, and flesh? Then how did He construct from the flesh, nerves, and veins the outward limbs: the roundness of the head, the aperture of hearing, sight, the nose, the mouth, and the rest of the openings? Then He extended the hand and the leg and divided their ends into fingers, and divided the fingers into fingertips? Then how did He construct the inward organs: the heart [qalb], the stomach, the liver, the spleen, the lung, the womb, the bladder, and the intestinesâ€”each one with a specific form, a specific measure, for a specific function? Then how did He divide each one of these organs into other divisions? He constructed the eye from seven layers, each layer with a specific attribute and a specific form; if a single layer from them were lost, or an attribute from its attributes were removed, the eye would be incapacitated from sight. If we were to begin describing the wonders [aja'ib] and signs [ayat] in each single one of these organs, lifetimes would not suffice for it. So look now at the bonesâ€”they are solid, strong bodiesâ€”how did He create them from a lowly sperm-drop [nutfah sakhifah]?

a.g: And of His signs is the creation of the heavens and the earth and the diversity of your languages and your colors. Indeed in that are signs for those of knowledge.
And of His signs is your sleep by night and day and your seeking of His bounty. Indeed in that are signs for a people who listen.

And of His signs is [that] He shows you the lightning [causing] fear and aspiration, and He sends down rain from the sky by which He brings to life the earth after its lifelessness. Indeed in that are signs for a people who use reason.
And of His signs is that the heaven and earth remain by His command. Then when He calls you with a [single] call from the earth, immediately you will come forth.
And to Him belongs whoever is in the heavens and earth. All are to Him devoutly obedient.
And it is He who begins creation; then He repeats it, and that is [even] easier for Him. To Him belongs the highest attribute in the heavens and earth. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.

He presents to you an example from yourselves. Do you have among those whom your right hands possess any partners in what We have provided for you so that you are equal therein [and] would fear them as your fear of one another [within a partnership]? Thus do We detail the verses for a people who use reason.
But those who wrong follow their [own] desires without knowledge. Then who can guide one whom Allah has sent astray? And for them there are no helpers.

So direct your face toward the religion, inclining to truth. [Adhere to] the fitrah of Allah upon which He has created [all] people. No change should there be in the creation of Allah. That is the correct religion, but most of the people do not know.

Indeed, therefore Allah the Exalted has said: "Is there any doubt concerning Allah, the Originator of the heavens and the earth?" And for this reason, He sent the prophets, the blessings of Allah be upon them, to call the creation to Oneness [tawhid], so that they would say, "There is no god but Allah," and they were not commanded to say, "We have a god and the world has a god," for that was already ingrained in the innate disposition [fitra] of their intellects from the beginning of their emergence and in the prime of their youth. And therefore, the Almighty has said: "And if you ask them, 'Who created the heavens and the earth?' they will surely say, 'Allah.'" And He the Exalted said: "So set your face to the religion, uprightly. The innate disposition [fitra] of Allah upon which He has created mankind. There is no altering the creation of Allah. That is the upright religion." Thus, in the innate disposition [fitra] of man and the evidences of the Quran, there is what suffices from establishing the proof [burhan].

That He may reward those who have believed and done righteous deeds out of His bounty. Indeed, He does not like the disbelievers.

And of His signs is that He sends the winds as bringers of good tidings and to let you taste His mercy and so the ships may sail at His command and so you may seek of His bounty, and perhaps you will be grateful.

And We have already sent messengers before you to their peoples, and they came to them with clear evidences; then We took retribution from those who committed crimes, and incumbent upon Us was support of the believers.

It is Allah who sends the winds, and they stir the clouds and spread them in the sky however He wills, and He makes them fragments so you see the rain emerge from within them. And when He causes it to fall upon whom He wills of His servants, immediately they rejoice
Although they were, before it was sent down upon them - before that, in despair.
So observe the effects of the mercy of Allah - how He gives life to the earth after its lifelessness. Indeed, that [same one] will give life to the dead, and He is over all things competent.
But if We should send a [bad] wind and they saw [their crops] turned yellow, they would remain thereafter disbelievers.
So indeed, you will not make the dead hear, nor will you make the deaf hear the call when they turn their backs, retreating.
And you cannot guide the blind away from their error. You will only make hear those who believe in Our verses so they are Muslims [in submission to Allah].
Allah is the one who created you from weakness, then made after weakness strength, then made after strength weakness and white hair. He creates what He wills, and He is the Knowing, the Competent.
And the Day the Hour appears the criminals will swear they had remained but an hour. Thus they were deluded.
But those who were given knowledge and faith will say, "You remained the extent of Allah 's decree until the Day of Resurrection, and this is the Day of Resurrection, but you did not used to know."
So that Day, their excuse will not benefit those who wronged, nor will they be asked to appease [Allah].

And We have certainly presented to the people in this Qur'an from every [kind of] example. But, [O Muhammad], if you should bring them a sign, the disbelievers will surely say, "You [believers] are but falsifiers."
Thus does Allah seal the hearts of those who do not know.
So be patient. Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth. And let them not disquiet you who are not certain [in faith].
